Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: I stared at my phone, the screen lighting up with my manager’s message: “Handle this call personally, please. The customer is furious.” My headset felt heavier than usual. At the same time, my sister’s voice echoed from the hallway, “Come on, we’re leaving in ten minutes! Don’t make us late for Grandma’s birthday.” I could hear laughter and the clatter of dishes as my family gathered, expecting me to join them for the celebration. But the customer on the line was relentless, questioning every detail of our offer, his tone sharp and impatient. My manager expected me to calm him, to salvage the sale, to prove I could handle tough calls. My family expected me to be present, to help make memories, to show I cared. My heart pounded as I tried to listen to the customer’s complaints, but my mind kept drifting to the family waiting for me. I felt torn, pulled in two directions, the weight of both expectations pressing down on me, unsure which voice I should answer first.
